definition:
Let $X$ and $Y$ be manifolds, and let $f$ be a mapping $f: X \to Y$.
Choose $x \in X$, and let $y=f(x)$. Recall that
$df_x: T_x(X) \to T_y(Y)$ is the derivative of $f$ at $x$, and $T_z(Z)$
is the tangent space of manifold $Z$ at point $z$.

If $df_x$ is injective, then $f$ is said to be an *immersion at x*. If
$f$ is an immersion at every point, it is called an *immersion*.

If the image of $f$ is also closed, then $f$ is called a *closed
immersion*.

The notion of for schemes is the analog of this notion in algebraic
geometry.
